newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria's AIICO sees income rising.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria's AIICO sees income rising.

text.p: AIICO Insurance Plc, one of Nigeria's leading insurance firms, on Thursday said its income was poised to rise as gains from past investments fell due.
"Our investment income is sure to go up in the third quarter when we put into consideration gains from our investments in the capital market," said company secretary Aderemi Awosanmi.
The company's result for the first half of 1996 showed a drop in investment income to 64.1 million naira from 86.5 million in the corresponding period of 1995.
Gross premium was, however, up at 379 million naira, against 261.3 million naira in 1995.
One stockbroker told Reuters the fall in investment income was partly due to the drop in interest rates in the country's money market.
"Interest rates have fallen to 15 percent and may drop further as the PTF (Petroleum Trust Fund) releases more money into the economy," said Niyi Opeodu of Lead Investments Ltd.
The fund was set up by the military rulers in 1994 to cushion the blow of a four-fold increase in domestic fuel prices by investing the gains in public infrastructure.
Awosanmi said: "Investment income has dropped in view of low yields on deposits."
The maximum lending rate is officially fixed at 21 percent.
"We have withdrawn from the money market and have moved into the capital market where we are at least assured of good return on our investment," Awosanmi said.
Analysts said most insurance firms had lost huge sums in Nigeria's troubled money market in the last three years, especially in finance companies that had since folded up.
AIICO's pre-tax profit in the period was 22.2 million naira compared to 15.4 million naira last year, a good result in view of the tough operating environment, according to analysts.
The company had been able to plough back retained earnings into profitable investment, Tunde Ayeni, an analyst at CSL Stockbrokers, said.
"Any company showing an improvement over last year's result should be commended," Ayeni said.
Net profit rose to 20 million naira to end-June 1996 from 11.5 million naira in the corresponding period of 1995.
Awosanmi said AIICO's management would ensure prudent investments and a better result in the second half of 1996.
The company, owned by Nigerians and American Life Insurance Company (ALICO) of the U.S., was rewarded with a 10 kobo gain on the Nigerian stock market on Thursday. It ended at 6.00 naira.
